sourceOfFunds.purpose: The Project examined the utilitarian and aesthetic aspects of wood carving in the life of the people of this region. The study aimed to evaluate and develop an understanding of cultural change and its effects on wood work in Uttarakhand through field research and audio-video documentation.

This project will research and document the rich oral cultural heritage and seek methodology for conservation and protection that emphasize local community participation and give greater attention to this unique oral intangible cultural heritage of Uttarakhnd. The study will also explore ways that the local people can preserve their cultural heritage, so that it remains a vibrant and self-identified part of community life. Oral traditions are a holistic concept.

The town is set in a valley popularly known as "Soar" (root meaning is Cool) and lies in the centre of four hills Chandak, Dhwaj, Kumdar and Thal Kedar, and stretches in the southern flank to Jhulaghat demarcated by the Kali river that is the demarcation line between India and Nepal. It is also a gateway to the Himalayas from the north, as pilgrims trek through this town to the Kailash Mansarovar in Tibet.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: We are a registered NGO with16 years of hands on experience in advocacy and empowerment of persons(with special emphasis on children and women)with disability.Our basic aim is to educate train and assist them in finding their rightful place in the society and ensuretheir inclusion in all fields. Located at New Delhi we run a special school for children with intellectual disabiityin the age group of 5 to 16 years. On graduating from here the youngsters move to our vocationaltraining and production center where they are trained inskills and trades to enable them to earn aliving and stand on their own feet. Besides this we have an independent living center for persons with disability,an established parent support network and an extremely effective legal aid cell for providing pro -bonolegal counsel and spreading legal awareness among disabled people in disadvantaged areas. We have ubdertaken a number of research projects on behalf of the Government and other agencies which are working in the area of disability. An extensive website on disability related information(www.disabilityindia.org )is yet another effort in enabling empowerment. On 3rd December 2008, the honourable Vice President conferred the National Award for empowerment of disabled people to Society for Child Development in recognition of the outstanding contribution made by the NGO. The number of disabled children / youth who benefitted from our work in 2009 are listed below 1.Special Education,training and Therapy 1660 2.Imparted vocational training 80 3. Enabled ability to earn livelihood 40 4.Provided pro-bono legal services 350 5.Guided & assissted in slums to claim legitimate entitlements and rights 4500 6.Personal legal advise rendered to 15 7.Answered legal queries of disabled people by mail 1500 8. Diseminated information through our web site 100000 9. Conducted Trainig workshops & discussions for stake holders of disabled people 16000 Approx 19000 disabled people directly benefitted from our programs and there were 84000 indirect beneficiaries

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The Society for Conservation of Nature (SCON) is a non-profit, non-governmental organization, registered under the Society Act of Govt. of India. It was founded on July 22, 1998 with a mandate of serving as an intellectual force that provides awareness, research and policy inputs for sustainable development. Since its inception, SCON has organized a wide spectrum of activities including scientific talks, environmental awareness & community services. The SCON also undertakes the following activities from time to time on need basis.  Awareness programmes for national and international policy makers.  Regional workshops on issues related to environment and agriculture.  Field projects on agriculture and environment. Indian Nitrogen Group (ING) Reactive nitrogen dominated the attention of SCON throughout this decade, mainly due to our early realization of its importance. The need to synergies the scientific community around reactive N led SCON to establish the Indian Nitrogen Group (ING) during the INSA workshop of 2006. Through ING, SCON not only brought reactive N to the forefront of discussions in all the relevant ministries of the Indian government, planning commission, academia and industry, but also became the sole Indian representative in many international fora including the International Nitrogen Initiative (INI). The SCON persuaded the INI to establish a separate regional center in South Asia for coordinating its activities among the South Asian countries. When INI decided to set it up in New Delhi, SCON naturally became its partner of choice in the region. Thus, SCON established a South Asian Nitrogen Centre (SANC) in New Delhi in 2008.With the help of UNEP, INI andING-SCON, SANC held a South Asian workshop on Reactive Nitrogen in 2010 to galvanize the South Asian partners for regional N assessment and nutrient management.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: For 32 years the organisation has innovated green technologies in shelter, water and energy for creating sustainable green livelihoods. With more than 20 such technology solutions Development Alternatives has created around 1 million livelihoods benefiting over 5 million people. DA has pioneered mitigation and adaptation measures for rural communities by providing environmental solutions for climatic change. It works with the government at the central level and in several states such as Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Rajasthan. It has also delivered its green technologies in Sri Lanka, Nepal Bangladesh and parts of Africa. Major achievements of Development Alternatives include:  Development Alternatives was appointed as the technical agency to support and strengthen the State Knowledge Management Portal for Climate Change in Madhya Pradesh.  At the National level, DA played a leading role in strengthening the National Steering Committee of Climate Action Network South Asia (CANSA) resulting in active engagement of members to develop perspectives on climate finance, low carbon pathways for growth and Indias priorities for COP20 at Lima, Peru.  The work of Development Alternatives Group in the year 2014-15 reached out to over 700,000 people with information, capacities and services, generating over USD seven million worth economic transactions in local economies and preventing over 500,000 million to9nnes of carbon emissions through cleaner production process.  According to the Global Go to Think Tanks Rankings report 2015, issued by the University of Pennsylvanias International Relations Program DA is ranked 135th among the Top 175 best think tanks in the world. An exemplifying achievement for DA has been that out of 6846 Think Tanks worldwide, it has been recognized in a total of 15 categories out of 52.  Some of the other key achievements of DA in year 2014-15 are: o 30% increase in agri-productivity o 6800 hectares of land managed o 800 million litres of water conserved o 740,660 tonnes of waste utilized o 407,700 kWh green electricity generated o 1.4 million tonnes of top soil conserved o 4800 people organized into Common Interest Groups o 18,250 people educated on local governance issues o Knowledge and capacities of 410 professionals and public officials enhanced o 314,800 people accessed WASH services o 5350 people access clean energy o 60,000 women made literate o 6423 people trained on employability and vocational skills

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Since its inception, the Society for Disability and Rehabilitation Studies (SDRS) has been constantly registering significant contribution in disability sector as also social sciences at national and international levels. Despite paucity of resources, it has curved out a niche for itself in the realms of participatory action research, social development, grassroots level social services, advocacy and policy- making processes. The most notable achievement of the SDRS lies in developing and getting recognition for Disability Studies (by Ministry of Human Resource Development/ Government of India) as an academic discipline to be taught in universities and colleges throughout the country. Consequently, Disability Studies programmes have been started in several universities/ academic institutions (including IGNOU, BR Ambedkar University, Periyar, Gauhati and Alagappa universities) at the instance of the SDRS. The process is in full swing in certain other universities (including the Universities of Kerala) to launch a series of programmes on Disability Studies. In the sphere of disability advocacy, the SDRS has played a crucial role by taking up with concerned ministries/ departments/ organizations the cases of victimization and discrimination as also denial of basic human rights of the disadvantaged sections of society, including persons with disabilities (who are the aggrieved parties) at various levels, ranging from difficulty in issuance of Disability Certificate, Medical/ Clinical Referral Services, Accessibility and Education to Employment, Social Security, Promotion and Protection of Rights of Persons with Disabilities and Other Vulnerable Groups. Tens of thousands of persons with disabilities have so far been ensured justice at various levels. It is due to our sustained campaign that rights- based perspective of disability could be the cornerstone of 11th Five Year Plan on disability. Similarly, the issues related to disability have been incorporated into the Poll Manifestos of National and State Level Political Parties in certain Statesincluding Bihar, Himachal Pradesh, Karnataka and Maharashtra. Especially in the field of facilitating accessibility and implementation of three per cent reservation in education, employment and social security, it has been working uninterruptedly as an effective pressure group. The finalization of Report of 11th Five Year Plan Working Group on Empowering the Disabled (2007-2012), constituted by Planning Commission, Government of India under the chairmanship of Dr G. N. Karna (Honorary President of SDRS and a noted expert on Disability Studies/Human Rights). The SDRS has also been actively associated with Core Group on Disability, constituted by National Human Rights Commission/ Government of India to monitor the implementation of UN Convention on Rights of Persons with Disabilities by Central and State Governments. Quite recently, the SDRS has succeeded in getting the scourge of polio wiped out from a village named Mohan Budhiyam (falling under Pandual Block of Madhubani district of Bihar) affected by mass polio; as the NHRC took suo moto action on the petition moved by SDRS and directed the Government of Bihar to take appropriate corrective measures. This is the only organization in India to develop and promote teaching and research in the area of Disability Studies as academic foundation of disability rights movement.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Established in 1982, PRIA (Participatory Research in Asia) is a global centre for participatory research and training based in New Delhi. PRIA has field offices in 8 states and linkages with 3000 NGOs to deliver its programmes on the ground. PRIAs work is focused on empowerment of the excluded through capacity building, knowledge building and policy advocacy. Over three decades PRIA has promoted participation as empowerment, capacity building of community organisations, and peoples participation in governance. Initiatives are undertaken in the overall perspective of making democracy work for all  in the political system; democratic culture in families, communities, and society; and participatory democracy with active citizenship. PRIAs professional expertise and practical insights in the following areas are utilised by other civil society groups, NGOs, governments, donors, trade unions, private business and academic institutions around the world: Participatory development methodologies Institutional and human capacity building for social sector Womens leadership and political empowerment Citizen monitoring and social accountability of services Participatory governance in panchayati raj institutions and urban local bodies Municipal reforms and participatory planning Environmental and occupational health Corporate social responsibility initiatives Adult education and lifelong learning Gender mainstreaming in organisations (including preventing sexual harassment at work)

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Building upon the learnings from the study PRIA in collaboration with NITI Aayog undertook another study Catalysing Actions for District Development Planning by Consolidating Local Priorities to assess and harness the potential of DPCs in decentralised and participatory planning

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Samajik Suvida Sangam is an organization of Delhi Govrnment which focus on designed intervention with welfare of women with prime objective. Women form the nucleus of the family , community, society and nation. An empowered and enlighten women will ensure that her family benefit from her and will unleash a chain reaction that will push development agenda up the scale to encompass all in its entirety. This Women empowerment program is being implemented at SPOWAC Paharganj New Delhi..

This was a Two Year Project and a sanction of Rs. 1500000 was accorded by the ministry of Health and Family Welfare for carrying out IEC Activities for curtailing female feticide and Strengthening the Strewed child sex ratio. This Activity was undertaken by Spowac in Central Dist of Delhi and after the period of two yrs it was observed that there was a significant impact on the awareness.

Awaz Uthao Campaign is yet another initiative of Delhi Government which not only sensitizes the masses on the gender issue but also provide a platform for womens collective and formation of other core groups to raise voice against day to day harassment of women. it is our proud privilege to be one of the implementing agencies of this campaign in the central dist of Delhi. Generally it is seen that women are silent spectators to atrocities both inside the house and as well outside the house .

Mahila Panchayat program is program by the Delhi Commission for Women getting its grant from Women and Child Development. This Program is implemented in all vulnerable pockets of Delhi to stop Crime Against Women and to organize women collective groups who will act as Mahila Panchayat members and collectively come to the rescue of women when atrocities abuses occur. SPOWAC has its MP at Dwarka J J Colony Sector-1 where on an average one case is instigated and reconciled.
Swarna Jayanthy Shahari Rozgar Yojana SJSRY is a pregame for urban youth for imparting livelihood skills and arranging for loan to make them stand on their own feet.
tuberculosis Awareness program in collaboration with NGO Mamta is a project in central dist of Delhi to Identify Tuberculosis Cases and facilitate proper and timely medication.

SPOWAC has its office in Village Rajolaka which falls under Palwal District. Most of the people living here practice agriculture and there are many youth who are unemployed. There is a great need to develop this village and create all sorts of positive awareness. SPOWAC undertakes educational activities for all ages, adresses health issues for women and concentrates on health, hygiene and sanitation.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Children between the ages of 3 and 14 are taught basic social skills, arithmetic, Hindi and English alphabet as well as vocational training so that they may escape the cycle of poverty and become independent adults. They all receive hot meals every day, as well as regular health check-ups and gifts of clothing and stationery to enhance their well-being. Through its efforts, over 500 needy children have received quality education and care.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: SUNAINA Society for the Upliftment of National Arts of India has been dedicatedly working for the propagation of our culture through education, training, presentations and research in the therapeutic and beneficial effects of India Classical Dances on the Mind and the Body of the Learner. In this Direction: SUNAINA was registered in 4th April 1994 under the Societies Registration Act 1860. The first book Indian Classical Dances its Therapeutic Advantages was released by Sahitya Kala Parishad in a grand function at Triveni Kala Sangam which was lauded by press and media. Encouraging reviews came in TOI, Hindustan Times, Statesman etc. Many lecture demonstrations were conducted in schools and institutions like IGNCA IIC Delhi Tamil Sangam etc in and all over India. SUNAINA WHICH WAS REGISTERED WITH THE song AND Drama Division has presented with its talented artistes about 300 performances in the JJ colonies on social issues like prohibition, terrorism child labor etc. The training wing of SUNAINA Sudhakar many dance dramas Krishna Leela Tarangini Silapatikarama Rama Nataka Keertanas Nasha hi Nasha Swarasangam, Ashtalakshmi the Woman Nrityabharati is affiliated as a full fledged examination centre and conducts examinations upto degree level and trains upto M.A. level . Every year about 300 candidates both external and internal appear for the practical and theory exams. Nritybharati run by SUNAINA has also presented dance dramas choreographed by the President Guru Smt Kanaka Bala Ramayanam etc. Every year Nrityabharati students participate in the National level competitions at Cuttack Pune and Dehradun and have won 23 to 22 trophies every time. Every year SUNAINA presents the Annual Functions presenting seminars Annual programs etc. Every year in January 15 to 17 SUNAINA presents INDRADHANUSH Festival for young professional artistes . Every year SUNAINA presents CONFLUENCE a merging of Traditions in which Manipuri Kathak and Bharatanatyam were merged SUNAINA runs an education wing BMSCAC for the poor children of daily wagers and Afghanistan refugees etc. which is and innovative English medium school. AIMS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE SOCIETY To promote young and deserving artists in the field of dance and music To run programs of dance and music curriculum to make the learners sand on their own legs as performers choreographers and artistes. To create awareness among the pubic through lecture demonstrations and seminars on the benefits and treasures of dance. To present dance and music performances all over India and abroad on various themes to spread awareness among the masses on the greatness of these art forms. To publish write and distribute books journals magazines that enlighten the mass on the greatness of the arts. To make programs on social themes using classical dance To approach the Govt. for grants to present festivals conferences and seminars on dance and music and other art forms. To set an education system where art culture and spiritualism is part and parcel of the education system.
